questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with symptoms of seasonal allergies, including sneezing, rhinorrhea, and itchy eyes. The patient has a history of performing tasks requiring alertness throughout the day. Which antihistamines would be the most suitable choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Fexofenadine

Explanation:

  • Fexofenadine, a second-generation antihistamine, has minimal sedative effects due to its limited ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus, it is helpful in patients performing tasks requiring alertness during the day.
  • Sedation and drowsiness are common side effects of first-generation antihistamines, which can impair cognitive function and alertness, affecting the patient's ability to perform tasks requiring mental acuity throughout the day.

Drugs that act by blocking Histamine H1 receptors:

Generation

Drug

Side Effects

Generalised Uses

1st Generation

Diphenhydramine

(Option A)

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision

Allergy symptoms, Insomnia, Motion sickness

Chlorpheniramine

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth

Allergy symptoms

Hydroxyzine

(Option C)

Anxiety, Allergy symptoms, Pruritus

2nd Generation

Loratadine

(Option D)

Minimal sedation, dry mouth

Allergy symptoms, Urticaria

Cetirizine

Allergy symptoms, Itchiness, Urticaria

Fexofenadine

(Option B)

Non-sedating, minimal side effects

Allergy symptoms, Chronic idiopathic urticaria

questions.text: Which prostaglandin analogue is not used to conduct MTP (medical abortion) in the pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Latanoprost

Explanation:

  • Latanoprost is a PGE2 analogue that is used as a topical drug in the treatment of glaucoma.
  • It reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humour.
  • It plays no role in the medical termination of pregnancy.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy:

DOC: Misoprostol 400¬µg, 48 hours after 200 mg of Mifepristone administration.
  • Mifepristone is an anti-progesterone drug that makes the fetus non-viable.
  • Misoprostol is a PGE1 analogue that causes uterine contraction, thus expelling the abortus.

CLASS

DRUG

ACTION

PGE1 (Option A)

Misoprostol, Gemeprost
¬†

The uterine contraction expels the abortus.

PGE2 (Option B)

Dinoprostone

PGF2 alpha (Option C)

Carboprost, Dinoprost

Anti-progesterone

Mifepristone

It makes the fetus non-viable.

Anti-metabolite

Methotrexate

It can be used instead of mifepristone.

Not recommended as it has a higher chance of incomplete abortion.

questions.text: In a 35-year-old woman at 40 weeks gestation presenting with an unripe cervix and scheduled for induction, what is the preferred subtype of prostaglandin for cervical ripening in preparation for labour?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) PGE2

Explanation: PGE2 (Dinoprostone) is the drug of choice for cervical ripening. It only makes the cervix soft and ripe without affecting the uterine tone and motility.

questions.text:
Match the following anti-inflammatory drugs with their mechanism of action.

¬†


	
		
			
			1)¬†Corticosteroid
			
			
			a) Cyclooxygenase inhibition
			
		
		
			
			2)¬†NSAIDs
			
			
			b) Lipoxygenase inhibition
			
		
		
			
			3)¬†Zileuton
			
			
			c) Phospholipase A 2 inhibition
			
		
		
			
			4)¬†Licofelone
			
			
			d) Platelet-activating receptor blocker
			
		
		
			
			5)¬†Apafant
			
			
			e) COX + LOX inhibition
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-e, 5-d

Explanation:

Drug

Mechanism of Action

Indications

Corticosteroids

Blocks phospholipase A2 enzyme, thus reducing the production of arachidonic acid.
  • Most effective anti-inflammatory.
  • Long-term usage causes Cushing syndrome.

NSAIDs

It blocks the cyclooxygenase enzyme and inhibits the conversion of arachidonic acid to prostaglandins.
  • Used in Gout, arthritis, musculoskeletal pain, dysmenorrhea etc
  • Long-term use can cause gastritis and renal failure.

Zileuton

Blocks 5-lipoxygenase enzyme.

Asthma.

Licofelone

Blocks both COX and LOX enzymes.

Controls inflammation in osteoarthritis.

Apafant

Blocks platelet-activating receptor.

Controls inflammation in acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with a known diagnosis of hereditary angioedema (HAE) presents to the ER with facial swelling and difficulty breathing. She reports that the symptoms started suddenly and have progressively worsened. Which drug can be used as a bradykinin B2 receptor blocker to treat the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Icatibant

Explanation:

  • Hereditary angioedema occurs due to defective/deficient C1 esterase inhibitor protein. This leads to unregulated activation of the complement system and kallikrein pathway, leading to excessive bradykinin production. Thus, exogenous C1 esterase inhibitors are used as first-line treatment to replace the deficient protein.
  • Icatibant is a bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist resistant to kinin enzymatic degradation and can be used as an alternative to C1 esterase inhibitor for treating hereditary angioedema.

Drugs acting on kinin-kallikrein system:

¬†

Drugs used for the management of hereditary angioedema include the following:

Prophylaxis

  • Drug of choice: Danazol (increases C1 esterase production)
¬†
  • Alternatives: Kallikrein antagonists
    • Lanadelumab: Monoclonal antibody against plasma kallikrein (Option B)
    • Berotralstat: Plasma enzyme blocker (Option C)

Treatment

  • Drug of choice: C1 esterase inhibitor.
¬†

Alternatives:

  • Kallikrein antagonist
    • Ecallantide: Potent enzyme inhibitor (Option D)
  • Bradykinin B2 receptor antagonist
    • Icatibant

questions.text:
Cimetidine can reduce the effectiveness of ketoconazole. Which of the following mechanisms explain this interaction?

¬†


	Cimetidine decreases gastric acid production, leading to reduced absorption of ketoconazole.
	Cimetidine delays gastric emptying, reducing the absorption rate of ketoconazole.¬†
	Cimetidine increases gastric pH, leading to reduced solubility and absorption of ketoconazole.
	Cimetidine induces liver enzymes, leading to increased clearance of ketoconazole.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 1, 3

Explanation:

  • Cimetidine, a H2 receptor antagonist, reduces gastric acid secretion, leading to decreased absorption of ketoconazole when administered concurrently.
  • This interaction can result in decreased efficacy of ketoconazole.
  • Cimetidine is also a¬†potent inhibitor of cytochrome P450 enzymes, leading to decreased metabolism of several drugs and subsequent elevation of their serum levels.
  • Theophylline, phenytoin, and warfarin are primarily metabolised by cytochrome P450 enzymes. Therefore, concurrent administration of cimetidine can lead to decreased metabolism and increased levels of these drugs, potentially causing toxicity due to elevated plasma concentrations.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient is being treated for peptic ulcer disease and presents with symptoms of breast tenderness and decreased libido. His current medication includes an H2 blocker. Which of the following H2 blockers is most likely responsible for these antiandrogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Cimetidine

Explanation:

  • Cimetidine is an H2 receptor antagonist that reduces gastric acid secretion in conditions such as peptic ulcer disease and GERD.
  • Notable side effects include CNS disturbances and antiandrogenic effects like gynecomastia.
  • Cimetidine is known for its antiandrogenic effects, including gynecomastia, breast tenderness, and decreased libido, due to its ability to inhibit estradiol metabolism and displace dihydrotestosterone from its receptor.

Ranitidine (Option A):

It has no significant antiandrogenic effects and is generally well-tolerated, with a lower risk of CNS effects and fewer drug interactions compared to cimetidine.

Famotidine (Option B):

It also lacks significant antiandrogenic effects and has minimal drug interactions. It is more potent and has a longer action duration than ranitidine and cimetidine.

Nizatidine (Option D):

It has no significant antiandrogenic effects and minimal drug interactions, with a similar efficacy and side effect profile to ranitidine, although it is used less frequently.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)¬†Hydroxyzine

Explanation: Hydroxyzine is a first-generation anti-histamine with a maximum anti-pruritic effect.

¬†

Drug Name

Primary Use

Antipruritic Effect

Mechanism of Action

Other Characteristics

Doxylamine

(Option A)

DOC for morning sickness

Moderate

Blocks H1 histamine receptors

Treat allergy symptoms and used as a short-term sleep aid due to its sedative effects

Meclizine

(Option B)

Sea sickness

Primarily used to prevent and treat nausea, vomiting, and dizziness caused by motion.

Hydroxyzine

(Option C)

Antipruritic, anxiolytic

Maximum

Blocks H1 histamine receptors and has central nervous system depressant activity.

Strong antihistamine used for treating itching, anxiety and as a sedative.

Chlorpheniramine

(Option D)

Allergic reactions

Mild to moderate

Blocks H1 histamine receptors

Commonly used for allergic reactions like hay fever and hives. It is the only first-generation antihistamine that can be given during the day.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of cardiac arrhythmias presents with symptoms of allergic rhinitis. The physician considers prescribing either terfenadine or fexofenadine for symptom relief. Which differentiating factors should be considered when selecting the appropriate antihistamine for this patient?

choices.text: Fexofenadine is more likely to cause sedation.
Fexofenadine is more potent than terfenadine.
Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.
Fexofenadine is more expensive than terfenadine.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)¬†Fexofenadine is less likely to cause cardiac toxicity.

Explanation:

  • Terfenadine, a first-generation antihistamine, is associated with a risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes, due to its effects on cardiac potassium channels.
  • In contrast, fexofenadine, the active metabolite of terfenadine, has a lower propensity for such cardiac adverse effects.

Feature

Terfenadine

Fexofenadine

Type

First-generation antihistamine

Second-generation antihistamine

Cardiac toxicity

Withdrawn due to risk of cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., Torsades de Pointes) when co-administered with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

(Note: CAT drugs - Cisapride, Astemizole, and Terfenadine have been withdrawn due to cardiotoxicity).

Generally considered safer with minimal risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

Drug Interactions

Prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

Less prone to interactions with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

CNS Penetration

Penetrates blood-brain barrier.

Poor penetration of the blood-brain barrier.

Pharmacokinetics

Metabolism leads to a longer half-life and duration of action.

Minimal metabolism, shorter half-life, and shorter duration of action.

Sedative Effects

It may cause sedation and impair psychomotor performance.

Minimal sedation or impairment of psychomotor performance.

¬†

Fexofenadine is more likely to cause sedation (Option A): Incorrect; both cause minimal sedation, and fexofenadine is less sedating.

Fexofenadine is more potent than terfenadine (Option B): Incorrect; potency is similar as fexofenadine is terfenadine‚Äôs active metabolite.

Fexofenadine is more expensive than terfenadine (Option D): Incorrect; cost is variable and not the main clinical differentiator.

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following is an ionotropic receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 5HT3

Explanation: 5HT3 is an ionotropic receptor.

¬†

Receptor type

5-HT1

5-HT2

5-HT3

5-HT4-7

Subtypes

5HT-1A, 5HT-1B, 5HT-1D, 5HT-1E, 5HT-1F, 5HT-1P.

 ¬† ¬† ¬†

Type of receptor

GPCR

GPCR

Ionotropic ligand-gated

GPCR

Mechanism

Inhibit serotonergic activity in the brain, and their agonist drugs are used in migraine prophylaxis and as anxiolytics.

Mediate vascular and visceral smooth muscle contraction, platelet aggregation and neuronal activation in the brain.

Elicit reflex effects like emesis, gut peristalsis, bradycardia, transient hypotension, apnoea, pain, and itch.

Mediate intestinal secretion and augmentation of peristalsis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is experiencing severe allergic reactions after eating shellfish. Her doctor prescribes a medication to help manage these symptoms. Which histamine receptors are primarily involved in regulating the allergic response?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) H1 receptor

Explanation: H1 receptors are primarily involved in regulating allergic responses, including smooth muscle contraction, increased vascular permeability, and stimulation of sensory nerve endings. Antihistamines that target H1 receptors are commonly used to alleviate symptoms of allergies and allergic reactions.

Receptor

Functions

Locations

H1 (OptionA)
  • Allergic responses
  • Smooth muscle contraction
  • Increased vascular permeability
  • Stimulation of sensory nerve endings.
  • Smooth muscle cells
  • Endothelial cells
  • Neurons
  • Immune cells

H2 (OptionB)
  • Gastric acid secretion
  • Airway mucus production
  • Vascular permeability
  • Parietal cells in the stomach lining.

H3 (OptionC)
  • Neurotransmitter release modulation
  • Central nervous system (CNS)

H4 (OptionD)
  • Immune responses
  • Chemotaxis
  • Cytokine production
  • Mast cells
  • Eosinophils
  • T cells

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is experiencing severe nausea and vomiting after chemotherapy. Her doctor prescribes a medication to help manage these symptoms. Which of the following medications is most likely to be prescribed?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Ondansetron

Explanation: Ondansetron is a selective 5-HT3 antagonist commonly used to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly in patients undergoing chemotherapy or radiation therapy.

¬†

5HT-3 Antagonists (Anti-motility drugs)

5HT-4 Agonists (Prokinetic drugs)

Action
  • Block 5HT-3 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and central nervous system.
  • Decrease intestinal motility and secretion.
  • Inhibit the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) in the area postrema, reducing nausea and vomiting.
  • Activate 5HT-4 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Increase gastrointestinal motility and secretion.
  • Enhances the release of acetylcholine from enteric neurons.

Drugs
  • Ondansetron (Option A)
  • Granisetron
  • Dolasetron
  • Palonosetron
  • Alosetron
  • Metoclopramide (Option B)
  • Cisapride (withdrawn due to QT prolongation) (Option C)
  • Tegaserod (restricted use due to cardiovascular risks) (Option D)

Uses
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV)
  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)
  • Radiation-induced nausea and vomiting (RINV)
  • Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhoea (IBS-D): Alosetron
  • Gastroparesis
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • Functional dyspepsia
  • Chronic constipation
  • Postoperative ileus

Adverse Effects

  • Headache
  • Constipation
  • Dizziness
  • Fatigue
  • Prolonged QT interval (rare)
  • Diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Prolonged QT interval (Cisapride, Tegaserod)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has been experiencing frequent and severe migraines. Her doctor recommends a medication that blocks 5HT-2 receptors to help prevent these attacks. Which of the following medications is most likely to be prescribed?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Cyproheptadine

Explanation:¬†

  • Cyproheptadine primarily blocks 5-HT2 receptors and has additional H1 antihistaminic, anticholinergic, and sedative properties.
  • It can be used in the prophylaxis of migraine.

Clinical Uses of Cyproheptadine include

  • Migraine prophylaxis.
  • Serotonin syndrome.
  • Carcinoid syndrome.
  • Cold urticaria.
  • Promote weight gain in AIDS patients.

Drugs that act by blocking 5-HT2 receptors (5HT-2 antagonists)

Drug

Uses

Cyproheptadine

Migraine prophylaxis, antihistamine

Methysergide

Migraine and cluster headache prophylaxis

Pizotifen

Migraine prophylaxis, antihistamine

Quetiapine (Option C)

Schizophrenia, bipolar disorder

Ketanserin (Option A)

Hypertension, peripheral vascular disease

Ritanserin (Option B)

Investigated for schizophrenia, depression, and sleep disorders

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of migraine without aura, currently on preventive medication, is planning to conceive. She seeks advice on safe medications for treating acute migraine attacks during pregnancy. Which of the following drugs is recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acetaminophen

Explanation:

  • Acetaminophen (Paracetamol) is the drug of choice (DOC) for both acute migraine attacks and migraine prophylaxis in pregnancy.
    ¬†
  • It is considered safe in all trimesters, widely studied, and not associated with teratogenicity.
    ¬†
  • It is preferred as the initial therapy before considering other agents like sumatriptan, which are reserved for resistant cases.
    ¬†

Migraine Management During Pregnancy

Purpose

Drug

Safety in Pregnancy

Comments

First-line (acute)

Acetaminophen

Safe in all trimesters

DOC for acute migraine attack in pregnancy

Step-up (acute)

Codeine

Use with caution

May be added if paracetamol alone is ineffective
¬†

Caffeine

Safe in moderation

Can be combined with paracetamol for enhanced effect
¬†

Metoclopramide

Relatively safe, some side effects

Can help with nausea associated with migraine

Rescue (acute)

Sumatriptan

Considered safe based on human data

Most evidence-based triptan; used when first-line fails

¬†

Migraine Prophylaxis in Pregnancy

Drug

Pregnancy Use

Notes

Acetaminophen

Safe ‚Äì DOC in pregnancy

Can be used regularly for mild prophylaxis

Propranolol

Used cautiously in 2nd/3rd trimester

Most preferred beta-blocker; used when non-drug measures fail

¬†

Sumatriptan (Option A):
Incorrect ‚Äì Although relatively safe and used when needed, it is not the DOC. Used as a second-line agent.
¬†

Flunarizine (Option C):
Incorrect ‚Äì Not recommended during pregnancy due to lack of safety data. It is used for prophylaxis outside pregnancy.
¬†

Propranolol (Option D):
Incorrect ‚Äì Used for prophylaxis, not acute treatment. Also requires cautious use later in pregnancy.
¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe migraine headache that has been ongoing for several hours. She reports that her headache is accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. She has tried over-the-counter pain relievers without relief. What medication would you prescribe to help alleviate her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Sumatriptan

Explanation: Sumatriptan is a more potent and specific migraine treatment that provides superior pain relief than paracetamol.

Mechanism of Action
  • It is a selective 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist that activates other subtypes of 5-HT1 receptors only at very high concentrations.
  • Inhibits the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and causes cranial vasoconstriction.

Administration and Efficacy
  • It is administered at the onset of a migraine attack and is as effective and better tolerated than ergotamine.
  • About 3/4 of patients obtain complete or significant relief within 2-3 hours.
  • Available in various formulations such as Oral tablets, Nasal sprays, Injections and Rectal suppositories.

Pharmacokinetics
  • It is absorbed rapidly and completely after subcutaneous injection, with an oral bioavailability of only 15%.
  • It is rapidly metabolised by MAO-A isoenzyme, and metabolites are excreted in urine, with an elimination half-life of approximately 2 hours.

Side Effects
  • Common side effects include tightness in the head and chest, feeling of heat and other paresthesias in the limbs, dizziness, and weakness. These are usually mild and short-lasting but can be dose-related.

Paracetamol (Option B): It is not effective enough for treating moderate to severe migraine pain. Sumatriptan is a more potent and specific migraine treatment that provides superior pain relief compared to paracetamol.

Telotristat (Option C): It is not indicated for treating acute migraine attacks. It is used to treat carcinoid syndrome diarrhoea.

Morphine (Option D): It is not recommended for migraine due to its side effects and potential for abuse. Opioids like morphine are generally not considered first-line treatments for migraine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the interaction between ergotamine and triptans in migraine treatment?

choices.text: Ergotamine and triptans have a synergistic effect, leading to enhanced vasoconstriction.
Ergotamine and triptans compete for the same receptor, leading to decreased efficacy of both drugs.
Ergotamine and triptans have no interaction and can be safely used together for migraine relief.
Concurrent use of ergotamine and triptans can lead to serotonin syndrome due to additive serotonin receptor agonism.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Ergotamine and triptans have a synergistic effect, leading to enhanced vasoconstriction.

Explanation:

  • Ergots have a mechanism of action similar to triptans. They stimulate the 5-HT1B/1D receptors but are non-selective, decreasing the release of CGRP.
  • They are more potent vasoconstrictors than triptans.
  • Ergotamine and triptans have a synergistic effect, leading to enhanced vasoconstriction, and hence should never be combined.
  • Side effects of Ergotamine
    • Coronary vasoconstriction (Angina and MI)
    • Gangrene of the extremities
    • Hypertension
    • Arrhythmias
    • Sweating
    • Bradycardia
  • Ergotamine is contraindicated in
    • Ischaemic heart disease
    • Hypertension
    • Epilepsy
    • Hepatic or renal impairment
    • Pregnancy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent headaches. She describes a severe throbbing headache on the right side of her head associated with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. She has tried over-the-counter pain relievers without relief. Triptans are being considered. Which of the following is the fastest-acting oral triptan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rizatriptan

¬†

Explanation:

  • Rizatriptan has the fastest onset of action among oral triptans.
    ¬†
  • Onset of relief begins within 30 minutes, which is quicker than other oral triptans.
    ¬†
  • It is highly lipophilic, allowing faster blood-brain barrier penetration.
    ¬†
  • Particularly useful for acute migraine attacks requiring rapid relief.
    ¬†

Sumatriptan (Option A):

  • Slower onset (45‚Äì60 mins) than rizatriptan; fastest only in subcutaneous form.

¬†

Almotriptan (Option C):

  • Onset is slower (~1‚Äì2 hours); well-tolerated but not fastest acting.

Zolmitriptan (Option D):

questions.text: Which medication among the following acts via the mechanism of action of antagonising calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Rimegepant

Explanation:

Pathophysiology of Migraine
  • Migraine is characterised by a pulsating unilateral headache that comes in bouts lasting 4-48 hours and is associated with nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light and sound, flashes of light, and vertigo.
¬†
  • 5th cranial nerve stimulation (5-HT1F receptor)

¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†‚Üì

Release of neurotransmitters like CGRP, neurokinin, Nitrous Oxide, 5-HT

¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†‚Üì

Dilation of meningeal vessels causing headache

Drugs used in acute treatment

  • Triptans: Decrease the release of CGRP and cause vasoconstriction. E.g., Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan.¬†(Option A ruled out)
  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab
  • CGRP receptor blockers: Rimegepant¬†(Option B)
  • 5-HT1F agonist: Causes inhibition of neuronal firing. E.g., Lasmiditan¬†(Option C ruled out)
  • Ergot alkaloids: Vasoconstrictor. E.g., Ergotamine
  • D2 Blockers: Metoclopramide¬†(Option D ruled out)
  • Opioids and NSAIDs
